utterances: Yes, it is.
I guess you must have some employees to help you keep track of 2,800 feet of meat.
Yes we do.
We have 15 employees.
Now these employees - these 15 employees - do some of them have health insurance through you?
Yes they do.
Is that costing you more and more?
Yes it is.
It's going up more and more.
In fact, we have to reevaluate it every year.
It's very difficult for a small businessperson.

This is an issue, healthcare, that Democrats say they want to be talking about in the coming Congress, and quite a few Republicans say they think it's going to be a major issue in the coming few years, as well.
Well, I sure hope so, because it's vitally important to employees, as well as senior citizens.
What do you want them to do?
I don't think that we should have a national healthcare, but I do think they should look into the insurance companies.
Because sometimes I think they kinda gouge people.
And I think they could look into that.
Are you a Republican, Ms. Ackerman?
I'm a registered Republican.
And you're in a state that has been Republican but that just elected a whole bunch of Democrats.
That's right.
Now, as the presidential, I voted Republican.
You voted for George W.
Bush.
Yes I did.
Then did you go vote for Democrats for Congress and Senate this time?
Well, I voted for our congresswoman, because I like her and I think she is going to do a good job.
Who is that?
Jean Schmidt.
Oh, Jean Schmidt.
Yes.
Now, she got in trouble, as I recall.
Well, honestly and truly, I think she was set up.
Let's review this for people who didn't follow this.
A Democratic member of Congress urged a redeployment of troops out of Iraq, and she ended up reading a public statement that appeared to call him a coward.
Well, the reason she did that, and she stated that, was there was another Republican within our state and in our area, who urged her to do that and then he backed down.
Which leads to the question of what your thoughts are on that subject of Iraq, I suppose.
Honestly, we just lost another soldier from our community, and I would like to see our boys and girls come home.
Well, Ms. Ackerman, as you know, we're talking to people along Route 50, here.
What's the drive like as you go east of Milford, Ohio?
The state of Ohio is called Beautiful Ohio, and it is pretty along 50.
Well let's go to Massieville, Ohio, then, which is where we found Jackie Baughman, who is our next guest.
Ms.
Baughman, welcome to the program.
Thank you.
And thanks for listening in to everybody else as we've gone along here.
What do you do for a living?
Well I imagine you've been up there quite a lot in this past year as things have gone up and down.
Yes.
It can change from one day to the next - going up or down.
What do you want Congress to do about energy prices?
Oh, I think Congress would do very well if they stopped worrying about their paycheck and started thinking about the people in this country.
I mean, we have resources.
We have oil fields in Alaska, and we don't utilize them to the people's best interest.
Well now as costly as it would be to take the drive for real, we are continuing on this journey on Route 50 toward Washington as we prepare for Congress to return this week.
And we're next going to follow it into West Virginia.
Has anybody here taken the drive that far?
We have.
My husband and I do this quite often.
Oh, Jean?
Jean Ackerman.
You will?
Yes.
What's it like out that way?
It's hilly and it's pretty.

Well I can't wait to get there tomorrow, and I've enjoyed talking with Dave Burt of Flora, Illinois, Gary Heichel of Bedford, Indiana, Jean Ackerman of Milford, Ohio and Jackie Baughman of Massieville, Ohio.
Thanks, folks.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Bye bye.
Bye bye.
And everybody was at work, and nobody got fired, so that's good.
